Hello blank fragment Click the camera icon to start analyzing the tomato plant! Bacterial wilt is caused by a soil-borne bacterium named "Ralstonia solanacearum" (formerly known as Pseudomonas solonacearum.) Tomato wilt bacterium mainly inhabits the roots, and enters the root system at points of injury caused by farm tools or equipment and soil pests. ABOUT THE DISEASE AND PATHOGEN Bacterial wilt caused by "Ralstonia solanacearum" is a serious disease of tomato plants. It survives for long periods in the soil, even in the absence of host plants. Even though there are now reported tolerant varieties, outbreaks of the disease can still be catastrophic problem. The pathogen enters the root system and stems through wounds caused by the damages through cultivation, human activity, nematodes or insects. SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS • You may observe the wilting of a few leaves. This often goes unnoticed just like how plants respond to drought stress and nutrient deficiency. • Under less favorable conditions, you may observe slower progression of wilts in the leaves, brownish discoloration in the base of a stem. • Later on, the entire plant suddenly wilts and eventually dies. CROP STAGE AFFECTED Appears in all growth stages of development. Before taking any action, read the symptoms and descriptions to make sure this diagnosis matches your problem. Otherwise, you can use the severity calculator to get the management advice. To know the severity, we need to use the Disease Severity Rating Scale (DSRS) based on wilting symptoms: • Implement a diverse crop rotation schedule with non-host plants such as legumes or grains to break the disease cycle and reduce pathogen buildup in the soil. 
• Practice strict sanitation measures by removing and destroying all crop debris, weeds, and volunteer tomato plants to eliminate potential sources of bacterial wilt inoculum.
• Optimize soil health and fertility through regular soil testing, balanced fertilization, and organic matter amendments to promote vigorous plant growth and resilience.
• Utilize mulching techniques with organic materials such as straw or compost to suppress weed growth, conserve soil moisture, and minimize soil splash dispersal of bacterial wilt pathogens. • Introduce beneficial microorganisms such as mycorrhizal fungi or rhizobacteria known to suppress soilborne pathogens and enhance plant health.
• Incorporate cover crops with biofumigant properties, such as mustard or rapeseed, into the rotation to release volatile compounds that inhibit pathogen activity. • Apply preventive applications of copper-based fungicides or biological control agents labeled for bacterial wilt suppression during transplanting or early vegetative growth stages.
• Use soil drenches or seed treatments with biological inoculants containing antagonistic microorganisms to enhance root system colonization and disease protection. • Implement a comprehensive scouting program to monitor for early signs of bacterial wilt infection, focusing on lower leaves, wilting, or yellowing symptoms.
• Maintain accurate records of field observations, weather conditions, and disease incidence to track trends and assess the effectiveness of management interventions. 
• Integrate bacterial wilt management into an overall IPM strategy that considers cultural, biological, and chemical control methods while minimizing environmental impacts and promoting sustainable agricultural practices.
 • Continue implementing crop rotation with non-host plants to disrupt the disease cycle and reduce pathogen pressure in the soil.
• Enhance sanitation practices by removing and destroying any infected plant debris promptly to prevent further spread of the disease.
 •Optimize irrigation scheduling and drainage to maintain optimal soil moisture levels and reduce stress on tomato plants.
• Practice careful weed management to eliminate potential alternate hosts and reduce competition for resources. • Expand the use of beneficial microbes such as Trichoderma spp. or Bacillus spp. known to suppress bacterial wilt pathogens and stimulate plant defenses.
• Incorporate cover crops with biofumigant properties, such as sudangrass or sorghum-sudangrass hybrids, to release allelochemicals that inhibit pathogen growth. • Consider targeted applications of systemic bactericides or biological control agents at critical growth stages to provide additional protection against bacterial wilt infection.
 • Rotate between different modes of action for chemical treatments to minimize the risk of pathogen resistance development. • Increase monitoring frequency to detect any changes in disease severity and adjust management strategies accordingly.
• Utilize predictive models or disease forecasting tools to anticipate periods of high disease risk and implement control measures proactively.
 • Implement advanced soil management techniques such as raised bed or furrow irrigation systems to improve water distribution and reduce soilborne pathogen movement.
• Consider using resistant or tolerant tomato varieties or rootstocks with known resistance to bacterial wilt to reduce disease incidence and severity.
• Adopt precision agriculture technologies such as remote sensing or soil moisture monitoring to optimize resource use and minimize stress on plants. • Explore the use of beneficial nematodes or predatory mites as biological control agents to target soil-dwelling stages of bacterial wilt pathogens.
• Investigate the potential for soil amendments with organic matter or compost to enhance soil biodiversity and suppress pathogen populations. • Apply systemic bactericides or nematicides as soil drenches or through drip irrigation systems to target bacterial wilt pathogens directly in the root zone.
• Consider the use of biopesticides or botanical extracts with known antimicrobial properties as alternative control options. • Utilize remote sensing technologies or aerial imaging to map disease hotspots and guide targeted management interventions.
• Integrate cultural, biological, and chemical control measures into an adaptive management plan that responds to changing disease dynamics and environmental conditions.
 • Implement emergency measures such as soil fumigation or solarization to reduce pathogen populations in severely affected areas before replanting.
• Consider implementing strict quarantine measures to prevent the movement of contaminated soil or plant material to uninfected areas.
• Evaluate the potential for alternative cropping systems or cover crops with known allelopathic effects to suppress bacterial wilt pathogens. • Investigate the use of microbial consortia or bioaugmentation strategies to enhance soil biodiversity and suppress pathogen activity.
• Explore the potential for using plant-derived biopesticides or botanical extracts with broad-spectrum antimicrobial properties as alternative control options. • Apply systemic bactericides or nematicides as a last resort to manage severe bacterial wilt outbreaks, following label instructions and local regulations.
• Consider the use of chemical soil sterilants or fumigants under expert guidance to eradicate bacterial wilt pathogens from heavily infested soil. • Conduct comprehensive post-harvest surveys to assess the effectiveness of control measures and identify areas for improvement.
 • Collaborate with agricultural extension services, research institutions, and industry partners to develop innovative solutions for managing bacterial wilt under high-severity conditions.
 • Focus on long-term soil remediation techniques such as phytoremediation or bioremediation to reduce pathogen populations and restore soil health.
• Explore alternative cropping systems or non-host plants as part of an integrated approach to break the disease cycle and reduce pathogen pressure.
• Consider implementing soil management practices such as biochar application or compost tea applications to enhance soil fertility and suppress pathogen activity. • Investigate the potential for using microbial consortia or beneficial insects as biological control agents to suppress bacterial wilt pathogens in severely affected areas.
• Explore the use of microbial inoculants or biostimulants with known plant growth-promoting properties to enhance plant vigor and resilience. • Consider soil sterilization techniques such as steam sterilization or solarization to eradicate bacterial wilt pathogens from severely infested soil before replanting.
• Evaluate the potential for using botanical extracts or essential oils with known antimicrobial properties as alternative control options for managing severe bacterial wilt outbreaks. • Collaborate with multidisciplinary teams of researchers, extension agents, and industry stakeholders to develop innovative solutions for managing bacterial wilt in severely affected areas.
• Conduct ongoing research and field trials to evaluate the efficacy of emerging control measures and develop evidence-based recommendations for growers facing severe bacterial wilt outbreaks.
 Level 1: Low Severity (0-20% DSI) Level 2: Mild Severity (21-40% DSI) Level 3: Moderate Severity (41-60% DSI) Level 4: High Severity (61-80% DSI)s Level 5: Very High Severity (81-100% DSI) The result shows that your plants are healthy The result shows early signs of bacterial wilt detected The result shows bacterial wilt progressing, action needed The result shows disease spreading rapidly, urgent action required Severe bacterial wilt outbreak, emergency intervention necessary A gentle reminder for taking care of your plant:

• Always water your tomato plant to maintain it's healthiness 💦 

• Tomatoes love being close to bright, sunny windows 😎 

• Apply fertilizers so that your tomatoes will like it and produce new growth 🌱 TOMATOTEC aims to create a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based model for detecting bacterial wilt. This incorporates science, technology, and agriculture. Alongside this, it utilizes the advancement of technology as an option to common methods. It is equipped to detect bacterial wilt disease in plants at an early stage. It allows the users to assimilate the severity of the disease coming from the bacterial wilt. Meet the dedicated individuals driving innovation at Tomatotec! Led by Joshua A. Aguedan, our UI/UX designer and full-stack developer and supported by our diligent researchers, Missy D. Tibo and Cerilo C. Dela Tonga. Together, we are focused on creating groundbreaking solutions with our mobile app, aimed at detecting bacterial wilt. Our diverse team is committed to developing technology that improves agricultural practices and supports growers in safeguarding their crops. We extend our heartfelt appreciation to our esteemed thesis advisers, Mr. Riz Rupert Ortiz, Ph.D. and Mr. Felix John M. Refanonte, whose profound expertise in image recognition algorithms, and Plant Pathology and Crop Protection has been instrumental in shaping the development of our mobile application, 'TOMATOTEC: A CNN-Based Model for Detecting Bacterial Wilt.' Also, we would like to express our gratitude to the Department of Agriculture - Calbayog City, Samar, especially to Mr. Arnold Derio, for helping us to plant the tomato plants that were used for our dataset.

Their relentless commitment to excellence, coupled with their invaluable guidance and unwavering support, has propelled our project to new heights. Their insightful feedback, meticulous attention to detail, and encouragement have not only enriched our academic journey but have also played a pivotal role in the success of this endeavor.

We are deeply grateful for their dedication, mentorship, and encouragement throughout the entirety of this project. Their profound impact will resonate far beyond the completion of this thesis, and we are honored to have had the privilege of working under their guidance. ReferencesActivity
